Summary : This is a labeled illustration and accompanying explanation of the operation of a hydraulic press, showing how force and pressure are transmitted through a hydraulic fluid between two pistons of different areas.

illustration:
# Diagram Overview :
  â€¢ The diagram shows two connected cylinders (left and right) filled with hydraulic fluid (labeled "Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø§Ø¦Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù‡ÙŠØ¯Ø±ÙˆÙ„ÙŠÙƒÙŠ").
  â€¢ The left cylinder contains a large piston with area "A" and force "F" applied downward.
  â€¢ The right cylinder contains a smaller piston with area "a" and force "f" applied downward.
  â€¢ Both pistons are at the same horizontal level, with vertical distances yâ‚ and yâ‚‚ marked.
  â€¢ The system is labeled as "Ø´ÙƒÙ„ (1)".

# Annotations & Labels :
  â€¢ Left piston: area "A", force "F", vertical distance "yâ‚".
  â€¢ Right piston: area "a", force "f", vertical distance "yâ‚‚".
  â€¢ Both pistons are shown pressing down on the hydraulic fluid.
  â€¢ The fluid is labeled "Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø§Ø¦Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù‡ÙŠØ¯Ø±ÙˆÙ„ÙŠÙƒÙŠ" (hydraulic fluid).

# Accompanying Text (Key Points) :
  â€¢ When the two pistons are at the same horizontal level and a force "f" is applied to the small piston, a pressure "P" is produced at the bottom of the small piston: P = f / a.
  â€¢ This pressure is transmitted equally throughout the fluid and to the bottom of the large piston, resulting in an upward force "F" on the large piston: P = F / A.
  â€¢ The explanation references Pascal's principle and the transmission of pressure in fluids.

# Equations :
  â€¢ P = f / a (pressure under the small piston)
  â€¢ P = F / A (pressure under the large piston)

Analysis :
  â€¢ The illustration and text together explain how a small force applied to a small-area piston can generate a much larger force on a large-area piston via hydraulic pressure, demonstrating the principle of the hydraulic press. The pressure is constant throughout the fluid, allowing force multiplication based on the ratio of piston areas. <!-- figure, from page 0 (l=0.081,t=0.072,r=0.892,b=0.243), with ID 0cddc843-b0bf-42cf-b9fc-ca2f575a95b4 -->

Summary : This illustration demonstrates the principle of hydraulic systems, showing how a force applied to a large piston is transmitted through an incompressible fluid to a smaller piston, resulting in a different force output.

illustration:
Scene Overview :
  â€¢ The image shows a U-shaped container filled with liquid, with two vertical cylinders of different diameters attached to each end.
  â€¢ The left cylinder is larger, labeled "A" (area) with a piston on top, and a downward force "F" applied.
  â€¢ The right cylinder is smaller, labeled "a" (area) with a piston on top, and a downward force "f" applied.
  â€¢ The liquid level is the same on both sides, indicating equilibrium.
  â€¢ The diagram is labeled in Persian as "Ø´Ú©Ù„ Û²" (Figure 2).

Technical Details :
  â€¢ No scale bar or units are provided.
  â€¢ The pistons are shown as solid disks fitting tightly in the cylinders.
  â€¢ The forces "F" and "f" are indicated by downward arrows.

Spatial Relationships :
  â€¢ The larger piston (A) is on the left, the smaller piston (a) is on the right.
  â€¢ The liquid connects both pistons, transmitting pressure between them.
  â€¢ The dashed line indicates equal liquid levels, signifying balanced pressure.

Analysis :
  â€¢ The illustration visually explains Pascal's principle: pressure applied to a confined fluid is transmitted undiminished throughout the fluid.
  â€¢ The system demonstrates how a small force on a small piston can balance a larger force on a larger piston if the ratio of forces equals the ratio of areas (F/A = f/a).
  â€¢ This is the foundational concept behind hydraulic lifts and presses. <!-- figure, from page 0 (l=0.062,t=0.472,r=0.278,b=0.611), with ID 2ad1970a-2f00-4a32-8079-29da246f2537 -->

Summary : This figure illustrates the pressure relationships in a hydraulic system with two pistons, comparing cases where the pistons are at different levels versus the same horizontal level, and provides the corresponding pressure equations.

diagram:
# Left and Center Panels: Pistons at Different Levels :
  â€¢ Both panels show a U-shaped tube filled with liquid, with two pistons (labeled 1 and 2) of areas "a" and "A" respectively.
  â€¢ A force "f" is applied to piston 1 (area "a") and a force "F" to piston 2 (area "A").
  â€¢ The liquid level under piston 2 is higher than under piston 1 by a height "h".
  â€¢ The pressure equality is stated as Pâ‚ = Pâ‚‚.
  â€¢ The pressure equation is given as: f/a = F/A + Ïgh, where Ï is the liquid density and g is gravitational acceleration.
  â€¢ Both panels are essentially the same, with minor differences in the depiction of the pistons' positions.

# Right Panel: Pistons at the Same Level :
  â€¢ Shows a U-shaped tube with pistons 1 and 2 at the same horizontal level.
  â€¢ Forces "f" and "F" are applied to pistons 1 and 2, respectively.
  â€¢ The pressure equality is Pâ‚ = Pâ‚‚.
  â€¢ The pressure equation simplifies to: f/a = F/A.

# Headings and Labels :
  â€¢ Top left and center: "Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙƒØ¨Ø³Ù€Ø§Ù† ÙÙŠ Ù…Ø³ØªÙˆÙŠÙŠÙ† Ù…Ø®ØªÙ„ÙÙŠÙ†" (The pistons at different levels).

  â€¢ Variables: f, F (forces); a, A (areas); h (height difference); Ï (density); g (gravity).

# Analysis :
  â€¢ When the pistons are at different levels, the pressure equation includes the hydrostatic term Ïgh, accounting for the height difference.
  â€¢ When the pistons are at the same level, the hydrostatic term vanishes, and the pressure ratio depends only on the force and area ratios.
